pyttn.utils.mode_combination module

class pyttn.utils.mode_combination.ModeCombination(nhilb=1, nbmax=1, blocksize=1)[source]

Bases: object

A class for automatically combining modes of a system_modes object together to form a new system_modes object consisting of composite modes. The approach implemented within this class involves sweeping from left to right and we attempt to combine the next mode into the current mode provided we have not already combined nbmax modes together in this mode and the local hilbert space dimension of the composite mode is less than nbmax.

Parameters:

  • nhilb (int, optional) – The maximum local Hilbert space dimension to allow during the mode combination process (default:1)

  • nbmax (int, optional) – The maximum number of modes to combine(default:1)

  • blocksize – An optional blocksize argument. For a blocksize of X, the current mode will contain a multiple of X modes and the

new mode to add will contain X modes provided we have not reached the end of the chain(default:1) :type blocksize: int, optional

mode_combination_array(mode_dims, mode_inds=None, _blocksize=None)[source]

Perform the mode combination process on a array of mode dimensions.

Parameters:

  • mode_dims (list or np.ndarray) – the mode dimensions

  • mode_inds (list or np.ndarray, optional) – the index labels of each of the modes (defaults to None) in which case we assume the modes are labelled [x for x in range(len(mode_dims))]

  • blocksize (int or None, optional) – An optional blocksize argument, used to ignore the globally set blocksize (default is None)

Returns:

The mode indices used to construct each composite mode. ret[0] contains the indices of the first composite mode

Return type:

list of list

pyttn.utils.visualise_tree.visualise_tree(tree, prog='dot', ax=None, node_size=500, linewidth=3, add_labels=True)[source]

A function for plotting an ntree object

Parameters:

  • tree (ntree) – The tree to be visualised

  • prog (Matplotlib Axes object, optional) – The visualisation function used with graphviz_layout (default: “dot”)

  • ax – Draw the tree in specified Matplotlib axes

  • node_size (int, optional) – The node size used for visualisation (default: 500)

  • linewidth (int, optional) – The width of edges connecting nodes (default: 3)

  • add_labels (bool, optional) – Whether or not to include the node labels (default: True)
